wikipedia_page.main: Joseph William Simpson (1879–1939) was a British painter and etcher of portraits and sporting subjects, and a magazine illustrator.

response: *Joseph Simpson (1879–1939) British painter and etcher of portraits and sporting subjects. He worked from a studio at 4 High Street, and rented 14a High Street from E A Hornel (1928 – 1929).

link_mentions.page: The Adventure of the Red Circle
response: "The Adventure of the Red Circle" was first published in the UK in The Strand Magazine in March–April 1911, and in the United States in the US edition of the Strand in April–May 1911.Smith (2014), p. 177. The story was published with three illustrations by H. M. Brock and one by Joseph Simpson in The Strand Magazine, and with the same illustrations in the US edition of the Strand.Cawthorne (2011), p. 141. It was included in the short story collection His Last Bow, which was published in the UK and the US in October 1917.Cawthorne (2011), p. 151.

In the Strand (UK), Joseph Simpson illustrated "When Doctors Disagree",McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D133.11. "Rough-Hew Them How We Will",McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D133.6. "The Man Who Disliked Cats",McIlvaine (1990), p. 183, D133.21. "Pots o' Money",McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D133.16. "Out of School",McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D133.10. "Three From Dunsterville",McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D133.14. and "The Goal-Keeper and the Plutocrat".McIlvaine (1990), p. 183, D133.17. In the same magazine, Charles Crombie illustrated "Something to Worry About",McIlvaine (1990), p. 183, D.133.27. "By Advice of Counsel",McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D133.8. and "The Good Angel".McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D133.4.

In the magazine publications, "Absent Treatment" was illustrated by Joseph Simpson (UK) and Wallace Morgan (US).McIlvaine (1990), p. 145, D15.5, and p. 182, D133.12. "Helping Freddie" was illustrated by H. M. Brock (UK)McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D113.15. and Phillipps Ward (US). "Disentangling Old Duggie" was illustrated by Alfred Leete (UK) and Wallace Morgan (US).McIlvaine (1990), p. 145, D15.6, and p. 183, D133.23. "Rallying Round Old George" was illustrated by Charles Crombie (UK) and Wallace Morgan (US).McIlvaine (1990), p. 145, D15.9, and p. 183, D133.25. "Doing Clarence a Bit of Good" was illustrated by Charles Crombie (UK)McIlvaine (1990), p. 183, D133.28. and James Montgomery Flagg (US). "Concealed Art" was illustrated by Alfred Leete (UK) and Will Grefé (US).McIlvaine (1990), p. 153, D50.2, and p. 183, D133.39. "The Test Case" was illustrated by Lewis Baumer (UK) and F. Foster Lincoln (US).McIlvaine (1990), p. 150, D34.1, and p. 172, D97.1.
Sir Joseph Simpson (1909–1968) was Commissioner of the London Metropolitan Police, 1958–1968.
*Sir Joseph Simpson (politician) (1908–1994), British-born Ugandan politician and businessman
*Joseph Simpson (artist) (1879–1939), British painter and etcher of portraits and sporting subjects

While Charles Edward Brock  painted in oils and was elected a member of the British Institution, H. M. Brock worked in advertising as well as in book illustration. For example, he illustrated Charles Dickens' Great Expectations, and produced four colour plates for a 1935 edition of A Christmas Carol.Various editions of A Christmas Carol on The Bookstall website  In addition, Brock was one of two artists (the other being Joseph Simpson (artist)) who contributed illustrations to Arthur Conan Doyle's 1911 Sherlock Holmes story, The Adventure of the Red Circle.The Adventure of the Red Circle at The Arthur Conan Doyle Encyclopedia. H.M. Brock provided illustrations for Susan Coolidge's "What Katy Did at Home and at School" Seely and Co (1911). Brock was a frequent exhibitor.
